review_full: I was thrilled to visit this restaurant per the numerous positive reviews here. Unfortunately, we were greeted disrespectfully, informed upon arrival that the kitchen was closing at 11 despite the hours posted of 12:30. The server staff laughed at our party of 3 (1 Spanish speaker, 2 non-natives) the entire time we were at the restaurant. This is truly disheartening as my friends had only recently arrived to Madrid following a 7 hour flight and were seeking a fulfilling meal. We ordered the Mediterranean platter which offered delicious hummus, average falafel and soft, tacky crackers for the dip. My veggie burger was undercooked with an over-toasted, stale bun. The flavors were very average at best. Quite disappointing and not destined to convert any non-meat eater.

title_review: Fantastic Spot for tranquility in Madrid
review_preview: Thoroughly enjoyed my time at La Terraza de Oscar Rooftop pool and would definitely return if I ever visit Madrid again. I was travelling with 2 girlfriends and we paid 35 euros each to use the rooftop pool and bar facilities between 3:00pm - 7:00pm...
review_full: Thoroughly enjoyed my time at La Terraza de Oscar Rooftop pool and would definitely return if I ever visit Madrid again. I was travelling with 2 girlfriends and we paid 35 euros each to use the rooftop pool and bar facilities between 3:00pm - 7:00pm and this included the use of a large cabana style sunbed, a complimentary drink on arrival, towel and locker/shower/changing room facilities. The pool and surrounding area was spotlessly clean with beautiful views over the city and the staff were extremely friendly and professional. This definitely felt like a high end, luxurious experience and we feel it was very good value for money. There was no music being played which made a very calm and relaxing atmosphere and there was plenty of space to unwind. Highly recommend this rooftop and my advise would be to pre-book your slot as it may be difficult to book on the day.

title_review: Certainly not the best vegan restaurant we tried in Madrid
review_preview: Perhaps we ordered the wrong dishes, but we tried quite a few vegan restaurants while we were in Madrid and, unfortunately, we weren't bowled over by the food in this one. For a start, the evening menu wasn't as extensive as the lunchtime one, which...
review_full: Perhaps we ordered the wrong dishes, but we tried quite a few vegan restaurants while we were in Madrid and, unfortunately, we weren't bowled over by the food in this one. For a start, the evening menu wasn't as extensive as the lunchtime one, which meant my husband couldn't order what he really wanted. We shared the Mediterranean taster plate to start. It was OK, although there weren't many mushrooms, which were the best things on the plate. The burger main only came with six wedge chips (!) and wasn't at all special. And the jackfruit tacos were fairly bland. The standard of the desserts was much better. My husband thought the caramelised apples were outstanding and my daughter and I enjoyed the cheesecake. The service was friendly, the interior nicely decorated and the location quite good. But we won't be going back.

title_review: I'm Now a Fan of Sweetbreads!
review_preview: Casa Toni is a neighborhood gem.  We never saw the upstairs but both nights we went there was a small table near the grill practically waiting for us to sit down.  It's a warm and welcoming place and our waiter even brought over the same...
review_full: Casa Toni is a neighborhood gem. We never saw the upstairs but both nights we went there was a small table near the grill practically waiting for us to sit down. It's a warm and welcoming place and our waiter even brought over the same drinks we'd ordered the previous night without us saying anything other than "hola". They are very busy but don't rush and we were astonished that he remembered us and our drinks order. We shared the pigs' ears, gazpacho, and shrimp in garlic one night and sweetbreads and gazpacho the second night, as well as rosado for me and beer for my husband. At the end of each meal our friendly waiter brought over small glasses of Muscatel.  The grilled ingredients are very good and Casa Toni is well worth a visit!

review_preview: The menú del día is amazing value at euros 10.50 for three courses including a drink and two types of 'proper' bread. We started with a small soup - delicious and peppery, then were offered a choice of three mains or a combo consisting of...
review_full: The menú del día is amazing value at euros 10.50 for three courses including a drink and two types of 'proper' bread. We started with a small soup - delicious and peppery, then were offered a choice of three mains or a combo consisting of a small portion of each dish. We went for the combo of seitan and chickpea stew, potatoes 'gajo' and couscous. All were very tasty - well seasoned and nicely spiced. Desserts were delicious too. This is definitely a place to return to, maybe for the lunchtime menu again, or maybe an evening meal from the interesting and varied a la carte. The restaurant was extremely busy, which is always a good sign that you're going to have a great meal. All those people can't be wrong.  The staff were warm and welcoming, taking time to explain to us first-timers how the menu worked, despite having lots of people to take care off. Next time we're in Madrid (probably for Davis Cup 2020 which was our reason for being in town this week) we'll be back!

review_preview: We were apprehensive about El Club Allard since we were convinced based on previous experiences that molecular gastronomy is a waste of time. But boy were we wrong. The back story for talented young chef, Maria Marte, is enough to convince any disbeliever. She arrived...
review_full: We were apprehensive about El Club Allard since we were convinced based on previous experiences that molecular gastronomy is a waste of time. But boy were we wrong. The back story for talented young chef, Maria Marte, is enough to convince any disbeliever. She arrived in Madrid from the Dominican Republic with no experience and started working as a dishwasher. Twelve years later she's the chef at a good but not great Madrid restaurant which had previously held single star for some years. Under her guidance the restaurant now has a second star, and, judging from our experience there, is headed for the greatest accolade, a third star. Everything is exquisite, from the first taste of the amuse bouche to the dessert. And to our surprise, we could see the point of the disassembly of the dishes to make something new. The wines, for the most part from the best Riojas, were excellent. If you can get a seat, go there. This is an experience not to be missed when you're in Madrid.

It was the first time for me to dine alone in a restaurant and I must say I was a bit nervous and shy.  As I walked in , I was greeted with smiles and was shown to my table , which was in the corner and I could observe the entire restaurant during dining .... I was the only solo guest there that night ....  My waiter's name was Miguel (if I'm not mistaken ) and was he awesome?! He even had a little conversation with me during dining , which I did find sweet of him.  I went for a 12 course choice dinner. Everything was so delicious and definitely worth every penny in my opinion.  By the end of the dinner the chef came to every table and asked how was the dinner and after thanked for coming in.  And after paying the bill they brought out the actual menus of what was served that night , written on a pretty paper and it also had a date on it as well.  My mind was blown and yes I'm keeping that menu for the rest of my life :)))  Never expected that dinner / experience to be so lovely.  Definitely recommend and I definitely will be back there again <3

review_full: If you are looking for unpretentious, traditional food, this is the place to go! I was looking for authentic tortillas, found a James Blick on YouTube and thought it was a great place to go eat. The first thing I did the morning I got to Madrid was going there! I didn't even check what time they opened, they were unfortunately closed at 9 AM, but I came back at 12 PM, and I do not regret that I came back later! The staff is extremely friendly, the place is cosy and close to touristic attractions, so when in Madrid, don't miss this gem!!

Food is beautifully presented.

title_review: Very elegant, I was made to very extremely special!

Attention to detail is clearly very high on the list of priorities and they do it so well. I will definately go back and it was a truly amazing experience for me andmy partner. I was also very pleasently surprised when at the end og the meal the staff came out with a Birthday creation (not a cake but a gorgeous candle and some mouthfuls of pudding! Just lovely and extremely thoughtful. This experience added greatly to the magical weekend my partner and I had in Madrid!!

review_preview: Months before a recent trip to Madrid, I booked a reservation for my wife and me at El Club Allard to celebrate our 30th wedding anniversary. I became interested in the restaurant after reading articles in El Pais and elsewhere about the restaurant and its...
review_full: Months before a recent trip to Madrid, I booked a reservation for my wife and me at El Club Allard to celebrate our 30th wedding anniversary. I became interested in the restaurant after reading articles in El Pais and elsewhere about the restaurant and its head chef, Maria Marte. We chose the ten-course tasting menu; a vegetarian version was prepared for me which I had requested when making the reservation. We enjoyed a succession of exquisite dishes prepared with a deep culinary understanding and commitment. Of course we had slight favorites and an occasional preparation may have been a bit saltier than what I would consider ideal but quality was always at the highest level and each provided a highly enjoyable moment, like unwrapping a series of gifts carefully chosen by someone who knows one very well. The vegetarian version was admirably well-done too, an unusual experience indeed. Every detail was thought-out and presented very well, from the extraordinary bread selection, all baked in house, to the Castillo de Canena olive oil, one of the most celebrated in Espana, which our waiter kept flowing for the fabulous bread.  The effort involved in such a production was obviously immense and the results were extraordinary. The staff, waiters, and sommelier were quite busy but nonetheless always sought to please in a manner of sincerity and utmost hospitality. The final tab reflected an expensive evening, as expected, but we were so pleased that we deemed the experience a great value. We could not have chosen a better establishment in which to celebrate our anniversary: our conclusion was that El Club Allard proved the best restaurant experience of our 30 years together. We look forward to returning with other family members in 2016.

review_preview: Everything we ate was more delicious than the last.  Everything was fresh and hot from the kitchen.  If anything we over-ate (but I'm not too bothered by it!).  In other words, four dishes for the two of us was more than enough.  Our choices: shrimp...
review_full: Everything we ate was more delicious than the last. Everything was fresh and hot from the kitchen. If anything we over-ate (but I'm not too bothered by it!). In other words, four dishes for the two of us was more than enough. Our choices: shrimp in garlic sauce, potatoes bravas, fried eggplant, and chorizos -- but there were lots of other tempting things there as well. There are a lot of great choices on the menu, and a goodly number of specials on the blackboards too. This is a small place that oozes authenticity. The seats are glorified stools, and there aren't too many of them. (There appears to be more space upstairs, but we didn't check it out.)  We got there for lunch at about 1:30 on a Saturday, and just beat the rush. Within 20 minutes the place was packed. Most of the people were drinking beer or wine. We thought we'd stick with water, but our waitress gave us complementary shots of sherry (delicious!) afterward, so we didn't stick with that idea.

title_review: A unique and wonderful dining experience
review_preview: Truthfully I've never been to a Michellin star-rated restaurant.  El Club Allard had so many wonderful reviews, we thought we'd try it.  We opted for lunch and chose the smaller course lunch (12 courses I think?).  It's hard to describe just how interesting and amazing...
review_full: Truthfully I've never been to a Michellin star-rated restaurant. El Club Allard had so many wonderful reviews, we thought we'd try it. We opted for lunch and chose the smaller course lunch (12 courses I think?). It's hard to describe just how interesting and amazing the courses were. In fact, just writing "interesting" would normally make me question it! I had forgotten (after reading reviews) that eating the business card was part of our first course. It was served with an onion foam. I'm, truthfully, not big on "foams", BUT it was ridiculously good and was eaten by tearing up our "business card" and dipping it into the foam. It was all my husband and I could do by not dipping our fingers into the bowl and wiping it clean. Each course was wonderful. My favorite was the truffle "cupcake". The decor is traditional old world. Chandeliers, big mirrors, rather formal. The staff seemed a little stiff and formal at first until they realized that we were there to have have fun and enjoy the experience. We had a good time talking with them. We ended with a view upstairs of the kitchen and the chef came out to greet us and thank us, which I thought was lovely considering the place was jam packed full. I also thought it was reasonably priced considering everything. I would highly recommend it it you are adventuresome and love good food.

title_review: A fun place to eat with the locals
review_preview: A fun place to rub shoulders with the locals.  Casa Toni is compact and buzzing with activity, a bit rough looking from the outside but full of character.We managed to grab a table on arrival, but most people had to wait several minutes until...
review_full: A fun place to rub shoulders with the locals. Casa Toni is compact and buzzing with activity, a bit rough looking from the outside but full of character. We managed to grab a table on arrival, but most people had to wait several minutes until one was freed up. The food is old fashioned tapas. We had Potatas Bravas with its spicy sauce, sauted kidneys, aubergine drizzled in honey, and pork skewers. Other more exotic options on the menu included lambs intestines, pigs ears, and tripe. Service is quick and no nonsense. If you want to get an idea of what Madrid's locals eat when they go out then Casa Toni is the place to go.

title_review: Grand Prix Lunch in a Global Gem
review_preview: OK, so you go to a place like El Club Allard for the high end cusine, unusual ingredients, and a fixed price menu.  You will spend at least 250 Euros for lunch, thus not making this place for everyone.  However, if you can get the...
review_full: OK, so you go to a place like El Club Allard for the high end cusine, unusual ingredients, and a fixed price menu. You will spend at least 250 Euros for lunch, thus not making this place for everyone. However, if you can get the urge to splurge and eat at one of the world's unique restaurants, then be prepared for an experience for the ages. Get dressed nicely. Skip the flip flops and cutoffs. There exists elegance, grace, and creative expression that take every day food and turns it into extraordinary jewels on your plate. There are multiple courses, great wines, champagne, and good old fashioned service (sometimes excellent, sometimes, "where did they go")? The restaurant is located near the Palace but is not easy to find. Look for the address number on the outside of the building. Walk up some stairs, you will see the entrance at the top of the stairs.  Bon appetit!

review_preview: I have been fortunate enough to dine at a number of one Michelin star restaurants over the years. But before El Club Allard, I had only had an opportunity to dine at one two Michelin star restaurant, the sadly closed Cyrus in Healdsburg, California. That...
review_full: I have been fortunate enough to dine at a number of one Michelin star restaurants over the years. But before El Club Allard, I had only had an opportunity to dine at one two Michelin star restaurant, the sadly closed Cyrus in Healdsburg, California. That dining experience at Cyrus however was so dramatically different than any other meal I have had, from the ambiance, to the service, to the food. It was a fantastic meal that I will remember forever.  I came into El Club Allard with lofty expectations given my previous experience at a two Michelin star restaurant. Sadly, El Club Allard failed to meet those expectations and even fell short of the experience I have had at a number of one Michelin star restaurants. While I certainly do not feel qualified to critique a restaurant of its pedigree, I cannot recommend dining at El Club Allard.  El Club Allard did have a lot in common with my dinner at Cyrus. The food was executed extremely well. Every component was treated with respect and cooked perfectly. The food was also seasoned aggressively (only a single dish required me to add salt to enhance it). The dishes were plated in an appealing manner and often with a welcome playfulness. The service was attentive. Given the above, it would probably seem as though I have a positive impression of my experience. Unfortunately the meal suffered from a few critical flaws, the most glaring of which was that there was simply not a course I will remember. The two courses that were legitimately excellent (a wild duck course and an Iberico pork course) were excellent but were outshined by preparations I have had at other restaurants (though the use of banana in the pork course was unique and enjoyable). When spending a significant amount on a tasting (and granted the restaurant is exceedingly reasonably priced for a two Michelin star restaurant), I expect dishes of the meal to be memorable. This was not the case and a cardinal sin for me. Another major failure for me was that a number of the dishes simply were not enjoyable. I find this less objectionable than a meal lacking memorable highs but still highly disappointing. At times my lack of enjoyment was because I was not a fan of the flavors. This I can fully accept (palates differ and restaurants of this caliber are supposed to push boundaries). At other times, it was because dishes seemed more focused on technique than on bringing joy to the diner. This menu was at its best when it took a superior ingredient (e.g. wild duck and Iberico pork) and simply prepared it so that the ingredient shined. This was too infrequently the case. Where the focus of a dish was on culinary technique and impact of presentation, it suffered for it at El Club Allard. This was not the case at Cyrus where the spectacle complemented food that stood on its own merit.  The last major shortcoming from me was in the service. While attentive, the service did not exude any warmth. That would have been tolerable except that the service also de-emphasized educating the diner. When I eat in a restaurant of this caliber where the techniques and ingredients used are often novel, I expect to be educated about this. This was not the case for me (perhaps my experience would have been different if I had been fluent in Spanish). This aspect proved to be a letdown. Again, I cannot presume to think I am qualified to critique a restaurant of this caliber. So this is just one man’s opinion. But I entered the meal intently focused on enjoying and savoring the experience. I left feeling very disappointed and wishing I had a memory to take away from the dinner other than now knowing every two star Michelin restaurant is not a sure thing. Maybe I was there on an off-night. Maybe the same meal spoke to others in a way it did not speak to me. But even with the exceedingly reasonable price tag, I cannot recommend dining at El Club Allard based on my experience.

title_review: Great dinner, beautiful presentations, cute restaurant.
review_preview: After much complaining about modern food, I managed to trick my Mother into letting me treat her to El Club Allard while I was in Madrid with my partner, and despite her original animosity, she ended up enjoying it, so 10 points for the restaurant...
review_full: After much complaining about modern food, I managed to trick my Mother into letting me treat her to El Club Allard while I was in Madrid with my partner, and despite her original animosity, she ended up enjoying it, so 10 points for the restaurant already: they accomplished their primary mission. The restaurant is located in one of the most gorgeous palaces in the centre of Madrid, in the corner of Ferraz with Plaza de España. I've taken innumerable pictures of that building without knowing I'd eventually see its insides. Inside, it feels like it should: an old house transformed into a modern restaurant, with elegantly spartan decoration. Since my Mother started the meal as a skeptic, I conceded going for the shortest of the three menus offered (much to my suffering) since that was her pre-condition. Portions were very appropriate for the length of the menu, and by the end of the dinner we were satisfied but not too full. Just perfect. Another good point about it is the relatively fair price for their fare, which is something that can be discussed about other Michelin starred restaurants. The meal started with a little silly surprise (do not read this paragraph if you don't want the spoiler!): we were brought a foamy bowl and instructed to eat it with the business card placed in front of us, which turned out to be made of some sort of potato paper. It was nicer than expected, but they need to improve on the texture of the card, which was too paper-y. Otherwise it was a fun thing to do, and we all laughed. Great way to break the ice when one of the diners isn't yet into the idea. Overall, the food was delicious in flavour, and generally well balanced, though we all agreed that two of the dishes needed work on the texture (the surprise one mentioned above, and another one presented as a muffin, which has a liquid centre: the muffin had crunchy parts that were way too hard). Dish presentation was fun, the ingredients used of great quality, and staff was very nice all through the dinner. Definitely recommendable for quiet friend reunions, small adult families, couples, or even small business meals.

title_review: Fantastic local place for tapas and wine in the heart of Madrid
review_preview: After spending way too much on a mediocre lunch at Plaza Mayor we decided to try a local place near our hotel in the Puerta del Sol area. Casa Toni is a tiny place, almost like a lunch counter, but oh man is the food...
review_full: After spending way too much on a mediocre lunch at Plaza Mayor we decided to try a local place near our hotel in the Puerta del Sol area. Casa Toni is a tiny place, almost like a lunch counter, but oh man is the food good. And the service is friendly and welcoming. We had a massive tomato salad with oregano and olive oil, a platter of grilled sweet peppers, and a skewer of pork with patatas bravas on the side. With a couple of copas of vino rosado, it was perfection. They comped us some jamon on the front end, a basket of bread, and some sweet wine at the end which was a perfect finish. Total for two was 19.50 Euros, an incredible value. Highly recommended -- don't be deterred by the appearance of this place.

review_preview: Not a great deal to add to the details of all the other superlative reviews. It's all true. We opted for the "medium-sized" Seduction menu - 12 courses. 12 courses sounds formidable but it's not at all the kind of food that means you need...
review_full: Not a great deal to add to the details of all the other superlative reviews. It's all true. We opted for the "medium-sized" Seduction menu - 12 courses. 12 courses sounds formidable but it's not at all the kind of food that means you need to release your belt before you even reach the dessert. Mind you, we were both a tad tipsy from the 5 wonderful wines chosen by the (nationally respected apparently) sommelier. The first wine in particularly was amazing - Aurumred 2013 - which contrary to what the name suggests is a white wine - a sauvignon blanc with the tang of hawthorn. Heavenly. I won't describe the food - I believe the surprise element is part of the fun - the very first item you nibble is INCREDIBLY surprising. It's just all delicate and creative and visually delightful. My only criticism is the waiting staff - don't get me wrong - they're incredibly professional and all that - but there is something military and po-faced and almost robotic about them - the occasional smile would not detract from the old-fashioned perfection. Overall, though, great and unforgettable.

Quite brilliantly executed and presented, full of clean distinct and complementary flavours that tease and titillate the senses in equal measure. To cap it all the utterly charming Maria Marte came out to chat towards the end of the meal and even allowed us a few cheesy selfies in the kitchen afterwards as she stood and prepared a huge tray of croquettas. This was an unforgettable meal in every respect - I would have no hesitation going back. Fine dining at its best.

review_preview: I've been adopted by Madrid and have fallen in love with it. After four years here I still go regularly - with both foreign and native friends - to Casa Toni. Warm service from Juan, David, Allen, Josefina and boss Carmelo. And exemplary food: raciones...
review_full: I've been adopted by Madrid and have fallen in love with it. After four years here I still go regularly - with both foreign and native friends - to Casa Toni.  Warm service from Juan, David, Allen, Josefina and boss Carmelo. And exemplary food: raciones at reasonable prices. Highlights include: chorizo, berenjena con miel (aubergine with honey), chopitos (deep fried baby squid), pinch moruno (skewered grilled pork in moroccoan spices) and their mushrooms. For bolder tastes, and being a classic Madrid tavern, their offal is great: the mollejas (sweetbreads) fried in garlic and parsley are lush as are their zarajos.  Good prices, solid wine, immensely fresh food and a 'typical' local ambience. I. love. this. bar.

Straightforward simply and hearty, home cooking is the order of the day. Late on a Sunday night, the joint was jumping - filled with young people, either beginning or ending their night. Sausage, sweetbreads, potatoes, eggplant - everything I tried was fantastic. Keep an eye out for this place, well worth a trip for lunch or dinner.

title_review: Michelin has me baffled with this one?? High's and Low's
review_preview: The dishes at this restaurant are a combination of peaks and troughs in my opinion. Some dishes from the tasting menu were visually stunning, some were visually dire. Some were of mediocre taste/texture, others were utterly sublime. The Maitre d', blatantly looked after those who,...
review_full: The dishes at this restaurant are a combination of peaks and troughs in my opinion. Some dishes from the tasting menu were visually stunning, some were visually dire. Some were of mediocre taste/texture, others were utterly sublime. The Maitre d', blatantly looked after those who, it looked like 'had a few quid', and gave us minimal time in comparison. It is not a 'cosy' restaurant, and things like the restrooms were very clinical, minimalistic, and cold. Don't get me wrong, I don't like 'old world pomp' of gold and drapes and all that nonsense, but this place just felt soulless. The head chef came out to all the tables, ours included, and it was all a bit embarrassing really, as if you have not had a mind blowing experience, then, what do you say??!!! I am not a fan of the current trend of flower arranging on plates to fill the white bits - I just want a balanced, tasty, plate of food. Having eaten at several two-Michelin star places in London, this sadly didn't hit the same level for me.

review_preview: Living in the Dominican Republic, and being a foodie, I have heard the fairy tale story of Cinderella from Jarabacoa who left to Madrid starting as a dishwasher to become a 2 star michelin chef at Club Allard in Madrid. So for my Mother's 70th...
review_full: Living in the Dominican Republic, and being a foodie, I have heard the fairy tale story of Cinderella from Jarabacoa who left to Madrid starting as a dishwasher to become a 2 star michelin chef at Club Allard in Madrid. So for my Mother's 70th birthday I made a point to get a table for all the family at Club Allard and have a tasting Menu prepared by Chef Maria Marte. I have eaten at several Michelin Star restaurants before but this was special. The fusion of Caribbean products with Old world ingredients make it special and very different. Each plate was unique and intriguing.  I can describe each plate of the tasting menu but it is impossible to explain the explosion of tastes in once mouth at each table spoon of food.  I suggest to any food lover that is passing by in Madrid to get a reservation before hand as there are only 9 tables and if you are really lucky for groups of 6 there is a special private room with a glass wall overlooking the kitchen which is a treat in itself seeing someone as passionate and professional as Maria Marte in her surroundings.

title_review: Followed advice from Rick Steve's book and he was right!
review_preview: This tiny place in an old part of Madrid very close to Puerta del Sol is worth the wait and a visit. We went there for lunch and returned for dinner later in our vacation. Everything we ordered was very good, the eggplant, boquerones, gazpacho,...
review_full: This tiny place in an old part of Madrid very close to Puerta del Sol is worth the wait and a visit. We went there for lunch and returned for dinner later in our vacation. Everything we ordered was very good, the eggplant, boquerones, gazpacho, all that we had was amazing. If it is very full, there is a room upstairs, but we prefer to eat down since it is cooler and nicer. The place is very full, but the service is fast and efficient as well as friendly and helpful.This is a great place to stop for tapas before a Flamenco Show, which we did. We went to "Las Patas" Flamenco very close from Casa Toni.

title_review: The best restaurant and food experience ever!

The place is first of all situated in a gorgeous building with no signs anywhere. There is simply an open door and candle light to the restaurant. The atmosphere is beyond words. Everything is so beautiful and perfect with a combination of old stylish buiding and modern decor. So to the food which is indescribable in its beauty and taste. The menu and everything is served with such creativity. The taste of each dish is lasting on your tongue for so long. I took the wine pairing and this too is excellent with local wines which are very nice. This was a unique experience in every way. Thank you El Club Allard for making our night a night to remember! You are worth a journey so I will be back!

review_full: We went to their Calle Preciados, 32 location for their 12.50E lunch special, which is only avaiIable at the bar, not on the terrace or dining room. You will not know this till you accidently sit outside and learn the hard way, when requesting the special(like we did). Luckily for us, we were entering a few minutes before the busy lunch crowd and found 2 seats at the bar. They were busy and it took a few minutes for the bar tender to take care of us. But, once the food started to arrive, the attentive staff were busy/efficient & we kept eating very well. We didn't think we would have room for the dessert, BUT, one always finds room for dessert!!!! It comes with free bread and 1 free beverage, but if you choose beer, then 2 free beers. I'm going back, but will visit one their other 9 locations, as we travel through Madrid. The also have El Gaucho a few blocks away at Calle Tetuan 34. It was packed the other evening when we walked past.

review_preview: Outstanding!!  This restaurant beats Per Se, Le Bernardin, Minibar and many other great places.  It pushes the limits of creativity but importantly, not to the detriment of fabulous taste.  It is a nice touch that the chef visits every table before and after the meal...

review_preview: The other reviews on the quality of the food, the attentive service, and value for the money are all true.  We tried this place for dinner last night and thoroughly enjoyed our evening there,  We arrived at about 8:45. and beat the crowds.  We were...
review_full: The other reviews on the quality of the food, the attentive service, and value for the money are all true. We tried this place for dinner last night and thoroughly enjoyed our evening there, We arrived at about 8:45. and beat the crowds. We were promptly seated and provided with menus. The time to take our order was a bit long, but that was due to the crowds starting to arrive. We were a party of 4, and we ordered the grilled octopus, ham croquettes, shrimp risotto, grilled beef tenderloin, and potatoes in a paparika sauce, and a pitcher of sangria, The food arrived quickly, and was absolutely delicious. The sangria had bits of sliced fruit and was served on ice and made a perfect accompaniment to the tapas. The portions were large, and we could not finish all the food, A piece of advice, potatoes are used quite a bit on the other dishes such as potato chips with the croquettes, and beef, as well as sliced potatoes with the grilled octopus, Had we known we would probably not have ordered a separate potato dish. To conclude the meal we were all given complimentary shots of a liquor similar to Bailey’s. We will be in Madrid for a few more days and expect to go back to this tapas bar to try some of their other tantalizing treats,

review_preview: The De Maria restaurant was recommended to us but not the one we visited! Apparently there are 4 or 5 De Maria restaurants in Madrid and I should have done my homework better. However it did not matter as the restaurant did not disappoint. The...
review_full: The De Maria restaurant was recommended to us but not the one we visited! Apparently there are 4 or 5 De Maria restaurants in Madrid and I should have done my homework better. However it did not matter as the restaurant did not disappoint. The staff were friendly and many extra were provided as described by other reviews. My partner had a steak with a sauce which he said was very good and I had the salmon pasta dish which was very creamy and delicious. The wine list was as expected from a restaurant of this calibre. Do not be put off by the road - Calle Hortaleza is a road off the Gran Via and as we walked up it it seemed to get more and more run down but we felt safe. Once inside the restaurant the ambience was great. Do try a De Maria restaurant - they specialise in Argentinian beef. My partner had the ribeye at another DM restaurant which he said was wonderful!!

review_preview: We booked Club Allard by email from Toronto and got a response within a day or 2. They also followed up with a reminder when we were actually in Madrid. This was our ‘blow out’ meal in Madrid and we had high expectations.  It wasn’t...
review_full: We booked Club Allard by email from Toronto and got a response within a day or 2. They also followed up with a reminder when we were actually in Madrid. This was our ‘blow out’ meal in Madrid and we had high expectations. It wasn’t easy to find – we were running late and arrived somewhat breathless. Fortunately we had read that it was on a corner, behind an iron door and up some stairs. The restaurant is a group of small rooms, somewhat formal looking. The chef, Diego Guerrero, comes out and meets with every guest and basically takes your order. He’s very personable and we were thrilled to meet him. They offer 3 tasting menus and we chose the “Seduction” menu. It was 12 small courses, each one amazing (3 snacks, 3 starters, 1 fish, 1 meat, 1 dessert appetizers, 2 desserts, coffee and petit fours). The server explained each course and how to eat it. We didn't order a bottle of wine (my husband doesn't drink), but I had a few glasses of wine (different whites) and then a cava. We finished with coffee. It was an incredible experience and well worth the approximately 228 euros bill. Service was excellent and the meal was well paced. At the end of the evening, Diego came by our table again to see how we had fared. We really appreciated the personalized service and loved the experience.

title_review: I think this chef could do even better......
review_preview: Having read the reviews of this restaurant, it was a must for our recent trip to Madrid - we went on Thursday 27th September for lunch.  Sadly we did not meet the chef, as others did, but the service was impeccable, the servers friendly and...
review_full: Having read the reviews of this restaurant, it was a must for our recent trip to Madrid - we went on Thursday 27th September for lunch. Sadly we did not meet the chef, as others did, but the service was impeccable, the servers friendly and as helpful as they could possibly be with our limited Spanish, and we had a highly enjoyable three hours over our meal. If I have one criticism it is that the humour and wit of a couple of courses overtook the balance of the food - the concept was inventive, but the execution didn't quite live up to it. (Spoiler alert if you've not been) By this I mean that the final, totally convincing egg, was of too sweet a chocolate - reminded me of Kinder egg chocolate - and that this, in combination with the chocolatey, coconutty sawdust, overbalanced the necessary tartness of the fruit yolk. The other slightly disappointing course was the taco, where the rabbit ragout was very meaty and succulent and, I thought, overpowered the rest of the dish. I think this chef is hugely talented, and would be happy to go back to try his other inventions. Don't let us put you off, though, go and be surprised and amazed yourselves!

review_preview: As a solo traveler I am always in search of restaurants which allow me to feel a part of the environment and engaged in spite of eating alone. Not only was the whole staff attentive, their interactions were characterized by kindness and a sincere desire...
review_full: As a solo traveler I am always in search of restaurants which allow me to feel a part of the environment and engaged in spite of eating alone. Not only was the whole staff attentive, their interactions were characterized by kindness and a sincere desire to create the best experience possible. The restaurant is used to travelers stopping by- and offered me a menu in Spanish and English. A small touch which is not only considerate but rather rare. I had the lunch special of the day which was two courses plus espresso. For only 9,90 euros!! Oswaldo was my server and he walked me through the menu with a smile. After the meal was over he offered me a delicious cream liquor shot— on the house! I so appreciate them engaging and talking with me about life, traveling, and the city of Madrid. Those human interactions are what define a truly incredible solo travel experience. I will be back! I can’t recommend this restaurant enough.

Ultimately, the menu was not exactly the same and there were some things missing from the menu at the "main" location. So I don't feel we had the same magic sauce as the other location. The garlic shrimp was Good. Everything else we had was Good, but not extraordinary, except the octopus. It wasn't bad it was just basic and after eating octopus many times in Spain it was just 101. The sangria was also 101. Our server who was the same person who walked us over was just not so happy that night. Maybe he wasn't happy with his “reassignment”. He just kind of did what he had to do, but in the end he did give us taste of after dinner drinks.

title_review: Delicious food and treated like family!

So glad we found De Maria. There are a few restaurants by this name. We went to the one on Calle Hortaleza 81 . The food was delicious! We all enjoyed the tasty soup and cava starters on the house, and then the green salad, loin steak, lemon chicken, fresh vegetables and potatoes. Wonderful, gratis, after dinner frozen peach (not sure but sure it was delicious) champagne, and two other desserts one, caramel filled chocolate and the other yogurt with a fruit topping, were great! The staff was warm and wonderful too! Couldn't have asked for a better last night in Madrid! Don't miss this fabulous, cozy restaurant!

The steak was beautifully prepared and the salad and vegies yummy. Cant say enough nice stuff about this place. All on top of excellent service. Best meal in Madrid by far. Well done team De Maria and thanks for being so welcoming and supportive of our little Spanish. Note if you want to tip (which we did) you need todo it in cash. Enjoy

review_full: We'd been advised to try another De Maria by friends who'd been here earlier in the year but found this one right by our hotel. Not disappointed. Ordered steak, chips and salad - all perfect. Steaks really well cooked, juicy and full of flavour (pepper sauce was amazing). Chips and salad were enough to feed five!! What made this special was the customer service and attention to providing an excellent experience. We were given a glass of cava on arrival (really nice too), followed by some toasted bread / cream cheese and a lovely pumpkin soup.  After our main courses we couldn't manage a dessert, but were presented with a complimentary mango cream and mango sorbet - followed by a mini bottle of liquor (two actually). This really is an excellent restaurant - the sangria is pretty special too.

title_review: Well presented food but not that tasty
review_preview: I feel bad giving only an 'average' rating to this restaurant.We have had a very pleasant dinner at El Club Allard. It is located in a superb building. We had dinner in a classy room, nicely decorated. The chef came to our table to...
review_full: I feel bad giving only an 'average' rating to this restaurant. We have had a very pleasant dinner at El Club Allard. It is located in a superb building. We had dinner in a classy room, nicely decorated. The chef came to our table to inquire about allergies and food we dislike. A very nice attention indeed.  Although the place used to be a very select club, one feels really at ease. The service is attentive, yet not intrusive. Waiters and the sommelier are very nice and were attentive to our needs; and each meal was well explained.  The wine list is very extensive. We know our wine but not so with Spanish ones so we followed the advice of the sommelier whose choice proved very good.  On the minus side: the sommelier and waiters do not seem to know how to pour wine. Each time drops of wine fell on the table. At the end of our meal there were many wine stains on the tablecloth. Not very classy... Ok, now the food. It is somehow inventive, and there is quite some attention to the way it is presented, with a few surprises (that I shall not reveal in this review. I think the less one reads about it the better, the element of discovery is part of the experience) My main (and major) complain is the food. What we got certainly was superbly presented, but taste wise, we were left wondering. Almost all our dishes were quite bland, bordering tastelessness. All other Michelin star restaurants food made my mouth water, with explosion of flavor to my taste buds. I am sorry to say this was not the case here.  Some dishes were interesting such as the Mini Babybell of Camembert trufee. The highlight was the Butter fish Tapa, which was truly excellent. But that was it. We left quite disappointed, wondering whether this was not a triumph of style over substance. There are three menus on offer. What differs between them is that some have more starters and snacks than others. We chose the menu Rendez Vous. (the 'short' one) At 85 euros, it is made of 10 dishes (2 snacks, 2 starters, 1 fish, 1 meat, 1 dessert appetizer, 2 desserts and coffee). Needless to say this is very good value for money. Overall, i was disappointed because I came with the expectations of a 2 Michelin star quality meal. I did not have that.  If you are simply looking for an unusual meal, and not too fussy about food quality, you certainly will want to try El Club Allard, which is well worth trying at this price range. The foodies will certainly be looking someplace else.

review_preview: Both my wife and I live to travel and try to combine a great trip with excellent meals. The last trip was to Madrid and we had many great meals ranging from michelin starred restaurants to tabernas and tapas. We ate at both La Terraza...
review_full: Both my wife and I live to travel and try to combine a great trip with excellent meals. The last trip was to Madrid and we had many great meals ranging from michelin starred restaurants to tabernas and tapas. We ate at both La Terraza del Casino and El Club Allard (but were unable to book Diverxo), We had lunch at El Club Allard and were pleasantly surprised when the Chef, Diego Guerrero, greeted us at the table. We chose the Seduction menu and left ourselves in his hands. I won't go into detail about each dish, but everything was prepared flawlessly. The portions are not large but after 11 courses were entirely satisfied. The pace is leisurely , the service impeccable. The wine list is extensive focusing on Spanish wines, but the rest of the world is well represented. we started off with a Cava and went onto a Ribera del Duero (Aalto) which was phenomenal. My favorite dishes were the butter fish tapa (I was hoping that one of the guest didn't eat fish), the game truffle with Foie and mushrooms (speechless), the salmon with saffron and sea urchin and the taco hare. But best of all the desserts. The fish bowl was amazing, so creative that I actually imagined the taste of the sea. The Poche egg a complete surprise. Yes El Club Allard is expensive but so is Alinea, Per Se, Carme Ruscalleda and Alkimia. Each offers a wild and unique experience,and well worth the price. El Club Allard probably is more faithful to regional cuisine but no less inventive.

review_full: We headed down on our first day to make a reservation the next day but it was full, however the manager placed us on waiting list and we got our table the next day for dinner. Do remember to make a reservation at least 2 weeks before.  The head chef came out to welcome us and introduced us to three different menus and also asked about our food preferences or allergies. We choose the revolution menu which had 3 appetizers, 4 starters, 1 fish, 1 meat, a dessert appertif and then 2 desserts followed by tea or coffee to finish off. Each of the dishes thar was served was an art by itself. We were constantly amazed by how humble foos ingredients look but was intepreted and served in a unique way of its own. Even the desserts of both the fish bowl and poached egg were amazingly created. Definitely worth the visit for a 2 star Michelin restaurant. We ordered two glasses of wine and the total bill racked up to 260 euros for the two of us. A must visit restaurant the next time you are in Madrid!!

title_review: Gorgeous food presented with a theatrical touch
review_preview: Fantastic restaurant - inventive food presented with a real theatrical flair. From the moment you sit down, and realise you can eat the restaurant business card on the table you know you're in for something a little unusual. Everything course of the taster menu has...
review_full: Fantastic restaurant - inventive food presented with a real theatrical flair. From the moment you sit down, and realise you can eat the restaurant business card on the table you know you're in for something a little unusual. Everything course of the taster menu has some exciting twist - smoke wafted with one dish to enhance the smell; food served over a lantern; a pudding disguised as an egg. Though most importantly the food tastes as well as looking amazing, the theatrical touches add to the experience of the food rather than detract from it.  Everything is spot on the food, the service and the ambience. Whilst not cheap - for food of this quality its good value (the wine list is particularly good value for a restaurant of this quality).

We were enthusiastically welcomed and had at least eight tapas courses for our group of 12. The house wine is excellent and you can see the food on display before it's prepared. We had an absolutely wonderful time here and by 8:30 there were many other patrons. This is an easy walk from Puerta del Sol and well worth the stroll.

A bottle of Rioja as well as excellent Spanish beer was also consumed along with an enormous plate of piquant peppers & bread. If I were to have a favourite hangout in the world, Casa Toni would be the place. Just go there.

review_preview: We were at this hotel in early March 2013 with friends. We go often to Michelin star restaurants, and given that this one holds two stars we will compare it to other 2 star restaurants we have been to. With that in mind I would...
review_full: We were at this hotel in early March 2013 with friends. We go often to Michelin star restaurants, and given that this one holds two stars we will compare it to other 2 star restaurants we have been to. With that in mind I would say that this restaurants ranks as a very nice one star...but probably doesn't deserve the second. Let me elaborate... The place  The restaurant is located on a second floor of an elegant building. Having said that it isn't easy to find as there were no obvious indications of the restaurant outside. The place itself was nice, sober and elegant so nothing to say there. The food One comes to a place like this for the food. Audi have to say one is not disappointed (completely at least). The dishes are innovative and some were very good. I have to say though, that although many dishes were good...none was truly exceptional. The fishbowl dessert was very nice, as was perhaps the fish...but somehow they felt just ok...so we found ourselves waiting for the dish that would completely surprise us...unfortunately it never came. Again, the food was not bad...quite the contrary, but often in a two star there is a moment of "amazement"... The service The service was discrete and adequate...having said that, for a two star, the service from the sommelier (assuming there was one as it wasn't really clear that he was actually qualified for the role) left some room for improvement. He brought us a bottle from the wrong year...and when we confronted him with the fact he apologized and said he didn't have any more bottles from the year in the menu...in a 2 star you expect that explanation before the bottle is brought to the table...not feeling that they were trying to "see if it would pass"... Overall Very pleasant experience with no "spikes"...the food was good, the place was pleasant...but somehow it didn't feel like a 2 star...of course it cost half what a French 2 star would cost...but don't know if "value" should be the driver of more stars...

review_preview: A triumphant journey from start to finish. This restaurant isn't for everyone. Firstly come with an open mind and let the team surprise you with all the taste explosions..secondly if your idea of good meal is a big chunk of meat and mountain of mash...
review_full: A triumphant journey from start to finish. This restaurant isn't for everyone. Firstly come with an open mind and let the team surprise you with all the taste explosions..secondly if your idea of good meal is a big chunk of meat and mountain of mash then I would skip this one. From outside you might not think this is a restaurant at all.There's no cheesy sign or banner out front only a friendly doorman who tells you that the restaurant is on the first floor on the right ( or second depends on where you are from ). There are several small rooms for individual guests or a big room for a larger group. Then you will be presented with three kinds of menu which you can choose. We were told if we are returning we can also choose what or not to repeat on the menu you choose which is rather quite flexible for this kind of restaurant. We did indulge ourself with the menu "la revolución silenciosa " which was the full tasting menu.  I don't want to get into much details here. But from start to finish it was a surprisingly wonderful. It's absolute worth the time and penny.  The staff is very friendly and helpful. The sommelier was particularly nice and we really enjoyed the chef to come to our table at the end of the meal.  Leave some times to enjoy and dress up a little. Just to be on the safe side. You can't go wrong with a blazer in this kind of establishment.

title_review: Not exactly Tapas but great nonetheless
review_preview: Taberna El Sur is advertised as a Tapas restaurant where you can order and share several small ‘tasters.’  There were a few Tapas offered as starters.  Undeterred three of us shared main dishes pork cheeks with potatoes (PHENOMENAL!!!), Paella (very good) and two mushroom and...
review_full: Taberna El Sur is advertised as a Tapas restaurant where you can order and share several small ‘tasters.’ There were a few Tapas offered as starters. Undeterred three of us shared main dishes pork cheeks with potatoes (PHENOMENAL!!!), Paella (very good) and two mushroom and two potatoe croquettes (okay). We also had olives and some amazing hearty bread that came with the meal. The portions were ample and it was enough to satisfy all. The service was excellent and they gave us complimentary digestives following dinner. We went early (7ish) and the place was packed by 8:00. Taberna El Sur provides good value for money and is well worth the visit if you’re in the area.

Had earlier in the day explored Plaza Del Angel area, and my wife and I decided to hit a tapas bar on the last night of our entry stay to Madrid before heading out to Toledo. Saw entry for Casa Toni in T.A. and gave it a try. Restaurant front was brightly lit and entry eatery was small with a window side table and low bench seats for 2. There was a long narrow table with stools for maybe 10 , a few bar stools at the counter next to a small bathroom sized kitchen and a table for 2 with taller stools, which we managed to grab adjacent to a stairwell to an upstairs space that seemed to swallow local patrons who were never seen again as well as being the location for the washrooms. The walls were decorated with photos of autographed flamenco dancers, bullfighters, celebrities posing with staff past and present as well as some what seemed to be pre or contemporary Franco era photos of Madrid. The long bench table was packed with Americans on a guided Tapas crawl, the window table with locals out for a while and the bar seats changed constantly with in and out traffic. It was even for Madrid unseasonably hot and the street was buzzing. We started with a few glasses of Sangria and were given our 1st tapas of pork on bread. We ordered a glass of white house and red wine as well as ordering potatoes with aeoli as well as piquante tomato sauce followed by a mushroom platter along with more wine, changing varieties as we went along. Might have forgotten some other dishes as well as wine service but everything was excellent. It was more of an event than a meal. Somewhere amid meal, American Tapas crawl was replaced by an Australian hosted crawl of a rather more subdued crowd of indeterminate nationality. The locals never reappeared from upstairs. The kitchen and waiters never paused to breath but were always attentive. We even got complementary Muscat at the end of our meal. Don't know if it's always like this or it might have been a perfect storm of temperature, patrons and personalities but it was an amazing adventure. Give it a try.

review_full: We went for lunch and left underwhelmed. The food was gorgeous. The descriptions were good, but the service had a strange way of framing the surprising twists and use of ingredients. It felt like the joke was on the guest rather than being in on it. Revealing that something already eaten was something actually something else left us confused and unable to appreciate what had been done. It was a nice setting, but you wish the effort didn't sacrifice taste. And at this price, this should never happen.

review_preview: Overall a great and interesting meal. The chupito was the highlight. Service was interestingly not so great for a 2 Michelin star restaurant. We waited for 5 minutes at the door as they fumbled around with tables. The courses were served with explanations only in...
review_full: Overall a great and interesting meal. The chupito was the highlight. Service was interestingly not so great for a 2 Michelin star restaurant. We waited for 5 minutes at the door as they fumbled around with tables. The courses were served with explanations only in Spanish, my fault I don't speak enough Spanish, and eventually no discussion of the food; coupled with wine and wine spillage. I have eaten in many Michelin starred restaurants and found it interesting that the service in some non starred restaurants is highly above those encountered in Spain. I love Spain but then I guess I don't understand the service nature. The restaurant was "booked out" for lunch, however there were many tables empty. Overall a great meal with lots of fun elements; the pizzara (blackboard) for example.The location is easy to find...if you know it is there. There is no signage making it seem a little exclusive. Will I go back - yes of course. At 260 euros for 2 including the associated wines is good value by Australian standards.

review_preview: Decided on El Club Allard as a result of the mainly positive reviews on Trip Advisor. Our party opted for the Seduction menu and  each of the 12 innovative courses' was given individual appraisal as they were consumed.Very mixed comments accompanied each one. Although every...
review_full: Decided on El Club Allard as a result of the mainly positive reviews on Trip Advisor. Our party opted for the Seduction menu and each of the 12 innovative courses' was given individual appraisal as they were consumed.Very mixed comments accompanied each one. Although every course was beautifully and in some cases spectacularly presented, as one of the Trip Advisor reviewers commented it is the food that matters. The concentus of opinion in our group was one of the blandness of the majority of the dishes. The addition of the infused foam on certain dishes only seemed to kill rather enhance the flavour. It is obvious to anyone who visits El Club Allard that a great deal of time effort and ingenuity has gone in to the creation and execution of these dishes, but the nuances & subtle flavour experiences get lost somewhere. The whole appeared to taste less than the sum of the ingredient parts, sadly.  The wine varieties from Ourense in Galicia, Avila & Cigales in Castilla y Leon, Mentrida in Castilla-La Mancha and a Malaga dessert wine, although not your normal wine fayre, just being different and refreshing is no substitute if in our groups opinion, they were all generally a bit on the lightweight side. The service was discreet and informative, the ambiance fine albeit slightly subdued given the number of dinners that evening. I am sorry, but for all our party, who are no shrinking violets when it comes to the enjoyment of gourmet fine dining and who had been anticipating something really special that evening, it turned out to be a case of style over substance. .

title_review: Imaginative, creative ... great way to spend an afternoon.
review_preview: Diego Guerrero's El Club Allard is superb ... a feast for all the senses ... we opted for the  Revolution menu, and were delighted with our choice. In a restaurant of this standard, while important the standard of staff, the room etc are a given...
review_full: Diego Guerrero's El Club Allard is superb ... a feast for all the senses ... we opted for the Revolution menu, and were delighted with our choice.  In a restaurant of this standard, while important the standard of staff, the room etc are a given (and lived up to expectations) ... it is the food which should shine, and so it did ... in fact it dazzled. So much caught our attention: - the game truffle - the mini babybell - the egg with bread and bacon over a potato sauce  - the pigeon - the 'sea dessert' with raspberry and white chocolate coral, dark chocolate mussel shell and marshmallow nemo - the egg  We really think that Diego Guerrero is developing ideas which are at the forefront of cooking and presentation today.  Sublime ... and for what it is, very good value. Go there ...

review_preview: El Club Allard is located in a grand turn of the century building which is located next to Plaza Espana. There is nothing on the exterior of this building to indicate that the restaurant is within this building. Look for the number 2 above the...
review_full: El Club Allard is located in a grand turn of the century building which is located next to Plaza Espana. There is nothing on the exterior of this building to indicate that the restaurant is within this building. Look for the number 2 above the door. The doorman will direct you to the restaurant located on the second floor. This is a very formal restaurant. I went for lunch and the some patrons were casually dressed. Most of the male patrons wore a coat and tie.  Diego Guerrero of el Club Allard is one of the few chefs on the planet that can combine seemingly random ingredients in a coherent way. His menu is a feast for nearly all the senses. Each dish is a work of art. Some delicate. Some whimsical. Some are just over the top. All are a feast for the eyes. The subtle and yet sometimes startling combinations of taste and textures was thrilling in one dish but left me confused in another. Such is the risk of cutting edge cuisine. Diego Guerrero is a maestro of the culinary arts. Eating here is a memorable event.   Fourteen courses, six different wines and a digestif. Lunch from 13h30 to 16H15. What a way to spend an afternoon.

title_review: Elegant restaurant with great food and superb service
review_preview: We went to El Club Allard on business.  I believe it is sort of a social club and that this is their restaurant, but frankly am not sure.  What I do know is that if I were to give anyone the address and say this...
review_full: We went to El Club Allard on business. I believe it is sort of a social club and that this is their restaurant, but frankly am not sure. What I do know is that if I were to give anyone the address and say this pace is a restaraunt people would not think so when they arrive to the location. The great thing was that you can get tables in small rooms and close the doors and therefore be in a very private environment.  The service is exceptional. The waiters are focused on the client being extremely satisfied. We had a 10 course degustation meal which was quite exquisite. The waiters would come and explain each coure: how it was prepared and how to eat it. It was really extremely delicious. title_review: Great place, even if communication was a little hard
review_preview: I visited this restaurant with my friend, another Spanish friend had recommended it to us, and we were not disappointed. We arrived having not made a reservation but where welcomed and allowed to choose where we wanted to sit. The atmosphere was friendly and relaxed,...
review_full: I visited this restaurant with my friend, another Spanish friend had recommended it to us, and we were not disappointed. We arrived having not made a reservation but where welcomed and allowed to choose where we wanted to sit. The atmosphere was friendly and relaxed, most diners were Spanish but we could have been at home. The staff didn't speak much English but we didn't speak much Spanish or Italian either, so ordering took a little longer than normal but it wasn't a problem for them or us. I ordered the mussels and my friend the caprese salad and the portions were enormous. Neither of us finished because we wanted to sample the mains (lasagne and porcini mushroom risotto). These again were both delicious. We had a nice long break after these (about 25 minutes) so we called have dessert. We couldn't come all that way without sampling them lol. I ordered tiramisu and my friend raspberry cheesecake, both of which were light and tasty. We had 2 bottles of wine and water and were amazed when the mere was a great deal at €110. We were then given a small decanter of limoncello to wash it all down X. The restaurant was clean and elegantly decorated. The staff were welcoming, attentive and very polite. All in all it was a fabulous night out and I would highly recommend a visit (€6 in a taxi from the centre of Madrid) I'll be there next time I'm in Madrid .

review_preview: After spending almost a week in Spain and a few days in Morocco, my sisters, mom and I returned to Madrid for our return flight. Although we had had our fair share of local food we still wanted to eat at a high rated, local...
review_full: After spending almost a week in Spain and a few days in Morocco, my sisters, mom and I returned to Madrid for our return flight. Although we had had our fair share of local food we still wanted to eat at a high rated, local restaurant. After seeing reviews on TripAdvisor, I decided on De Maria. My sister and I will tell you, it did not disappoint. It was so wonderful to have an amazing ribeye and salad after eating nothing but tapas for days! Do not mistake it for a typical Steakhouse either. We sat at the bar and watched the steaks being cooked on the grill while we were treated like royalty by our waiter, Tito! Complimentary appetizers as well as dessert were just a small part of this wonderful treatment! I read that this is not out of the ordinary. It reminded me of a Fleming's Steakhouse (because of the service), but the food selection was unique. I would definitely go there again and again!!!  Note: We ordered take away for our mother and tired little sister and they had no problem preparing it at just the right time so that their food was right off the grill and had not been waiting under a heat lamp!

I had salmon pasta and my partner had the ribeye steak..both delicious.. whilst we studied the desert menu, we were treated to complimentary mango sorbet.. we shared a brownie with ice cream.. delicious! Then.. a complimentary glass of champagne and some chocolates! The waiters were all lovely.. the food was great and the attention to detail made the evening very special.. would definitely go again should we visit Madrid in the future.

review_preview: I enjoy eating the "unwanted" bits and experiencing authentic local fare so Casa Toni definitely did not disappoint.  The restaurant is small and unassuming with a ton of Spanish charm.  We took a small table by the entrance and were immediately approached by a server...
review_full: I enjoy eating the "unwanted" bits and experiencing authentic local fare so Casa Toni definitely did not disappoint. The restaurant is small and unassuming with a ton of Spanish charm. We took a small table by the entrance and were immediately approached by a server with a massive smile. Our drinks were served promptly with a complimentary tapas of bread and ham drizzled in olive oil and garnished with a sprinkle of paprika. Not large, but enough to tide you over until your order arrives. Although super full from lunch, my mission that day was to try the Orejas and we ordered the lambs kidneys as well. The Orejas ala plancha (pigs ears) came piping hot, perfectly seasoned morsels of soft, crunchy, grilled delight! Pigs ears are quite soft and fatty so you do need to be mentally prepared for the texture if you've never had them before, and they're served with a side sauce that tasted of roast capsicum, tomato and garlic (I didn't ask) which was a fresh zingy counter foil to the juicy Orejas. The Riñones a la plancha were equally tasty slices of lamb kidneys cooked perfectly on a hot grill and served with a wedge of lemon to squeeze over. Firm yet tender, the kidneys did not have an overwhelming taste of sheep (or offal), well cleaned and prepared. Portion size is perfect for two (hungry) people, however we were full from lunch and could not finish the dish. When we were done, we were served a complimentary digestif which was lovely and very much appreciated. I will be back one day to try the callos caseros (homemade tripe stew) which I've tried elsewhere and love. If you like offal, want to go local, and unpretentious.. this is a definite recommendation

title_review: Emotional response to the food was something first for me…
review_preview: If it wasn’t for TripAdvisor reviews I would most probably didn’t ever even walk by this place..Away from most tourist popular routs, but restaurant very popular with tourist and locals alike.Quite unassuming place from the outside. I could never tell it could be...
review_full: If it wasn’t for TripAdvisor reviews I would most probably didn’t ever even walk by this place.. Away from most tourist popular routs, but restaurant very popular with tourist and locals alike. Quite unassuming place from the outside. I could never tell it could be one of the most popular places to have a good meal in town. But deceivingly this is only one more sign of good things to expect.  First good sing – no table available for immediate seating. It took some shuffling with the serving staff to move few customers around to accommodate me with a seat at the bar. For the bar seat perspective, the place still looked more like a place to drop by for a drink, rather than for something to eat. Menus are prepared in few languages – a sing of popularity with people from all over.. I really was looking for a place with traditional Spanish cuisine, as I wanted to try a good traditional Paella, as God intended it for people to enjoy. It wasn’t on a menu, but it was my lucky day, as their had Paella on special that day. My choice was Slamorejo –tomato soup and of course I ordered a Paella as well. It took me a while before I was served my food, but after I had a first taste of Slamorejo, I was so shocked, I did not know how to react. I did not expect that at all… Emotional response to the food it was something first for me… Most probably the best tomato soup I have ever had in my life. Served cold, splashed with a bit of olive oil and topped with chopped ham and hardboiled egg.. Some wonderfully zesty taste (probably of lime) was elevating the sensational composition of flavors. I could not stop smiling to myself while eating. Bravo! I could have that soup for breakfast, lunch, dinner and in between snack… Paella on the other hand did not measure up to the sensational firs course. It was good. In fact - it was very good, but not the best I ever had. Presentation maybe wasn’t too appealing, but with this kind of dish, which meant to be peasant and not too fancy – the secret is in how it tastes not in how it looks. It was a good balance of flavors with some wonderful seafood enhancements. A good dish to have for a daily special. I did enjoy it. In overall – I’m so pleased I listen to all of you good people leaving your reviews.  I had a very good meal and I was happy to take a detour form the usual tourist trails to have it.  Moderately priced. Soup was 4.40 Euro, Paella was priced at 9,50 Euros. And that’s how it was. No hidden fees, no added service – hones food and hones pricing. Super friendly and quite handsome waiting staff just added to my positive experience. I will most definitely come back, as I will never be able to replicate that sensational soup recipe.

title_review: Take a chance. I did and it was worthwhile
review_preview: I had been walking around Madrid knowing that the better restaurants didn't open until 20.00 and just before then I noticed the De Maria.  Menu outside looked good so I went in.  As they had not started serving I sat at the bar and had...
review_full: I had been walking around Madrid knowing that the better restaurants didn't open until 20.00 and just before then I noticed the De Maria. Menu outside looked good so I went in. As they had not started serving I sat at the bar and had a drink. The staff were very friendly and I was taken to my table a few minutes later. I ordered the ribs and french fries. I was given a hot soup canapé, which was very good, together with little pieces of toast and cream cheese. I saw from the bill I was not charged for this. I had ordered my ribs medium rare and that was exactly how they were served. They were excellent. I didn't need ant dessert but I was given a mango based cream sweet and mango yoghurt. Again they were very good and what was even better was that they were free. The staff were very friendly although some of them spoke little English it was better than my Spanish.  De Maria is a little gem to which I will return.

review_full: I read about Casa Toni when I googled "Best Tapas in Madrid". It was a few down the line and we actually didn't specifically seek it out, but stumbled upon it on a walk. My husband I loved our meal the first time, we went back two days later for lunch!! We had the fried anchovies and sweetbreads the first night and came back for the squid, chorizo, more anchovies and tomato salad the next time. We suggest getting 1/2 orders of each so you can try more things, because the portions are quite generous.

review_preview: One thing that struck me as odd was two diffrent menus they had. The local menu displayed outside was cheaper than the not-so ominously named "English menu".The prices could range from couple of euros to two times the price with slight difference on offered...
review_full: One thing that struck me as odd was two diffrent menus they had. The local menu displayed outside was cheaper than the not-so ominously named "English menu". The prices could range from couple of euros to two times the price with slight difference on offered items. This was evident on both De Maria restaurants I visited. Anyway. I had ribeye. Steak was served, as per custom with minimal garnishing, but it was large. Half a kilo large. The sides were horrendously expensive and I just had the hot potato as a side dish. I ordered medium rare. Got ultra rare, but it was fine still. The language barrier is hard to handle when they do not understand "salt and pepper" and instead make you pepper sauce, but it's part of the experience. It does seem that it's quite popular among locals because the house quickly filled up at noon. I wouldn't really reccomend this place, but If you have nowhere else to go then it's a passable experience.

title_review: Recommended by Trip Advisor, heartily agree
review_preview: Having trawled TA for a good place to eat on a Saturday night, my friends and I plumped to head here. Reviews had mentioned how busy the place is and this trip was no exception, however we were told that if we wanted to put...
review_full: Having trawled TA for a good place to eat on a Saturday night, my friends and I plumped to head here. Reviews had mentioned how busy the place is and this trip was no exception, however we were told that if we wanted to put our names down and have a drink at the bar it wouldn't be long before a table would become available. Sure enough, we were seated in about 10-15 mins. We decided on 5 plates which was plenty between 3 of us. Although the service wasn't always the most attentive (it was quite busy to be fair), all the staff were incredibly friendly and even threw in a cheeky shot as we were leaving. The food was absolutely delicious and very vfm.  Would highly recommend this restaurant although if you don't like waiting, I'd suggest booking.

review_preview: Some fine dining places are only about the food--the atmosphere is bare (so you do not look anywhere else but at the food), the floors are concrete (your feet need to concentrate on the food), and there is no music (in case hearing something pleasant...
review_full: Some fine dining places are only about the food--the atmosphere is bare (so you do not look anywhere else but at the food), the floors are concrete (your feet need to concentrate on the food), and there is no music (in case hearing something pleasant will cause some synesthesic reaction, where your taste buds dull and become stupid). But not at El Club Allard! Everything from the service to the cushy chairs and well-appointed rooms were focused on comfort. Our waiter was a cheeky and sweet guy who, even though he insisted his English was not good, communicated quite well and even dropped a Nemo reference, which meant he loved Disney movies. As other reviewers have pointed out, the meal begins with an edible card. Pretend to look surprised when they tell you to eat it--it makes them happy to think we haven't researched this place to death and can no longer appreciate surprises. But don't pretend you like it--it tasted pretty bad, especially in the peanut foam it comes with. Thankfully, this is merely for fun and not an indication of the overall meal. The courses were a mix of visually entertaining (the foie gras and truffle "terranium", the "under the sea" dessert with chocolate seaweed and a marshmallow fish otherwise known as Nemo, the egg dessert which look and felt exactly like an egg until you ate it and discovered that it was coconut panna cotta with mango filling), and the straightforwardly delicious (a simple piece of fluke atop a frozen perilla leaf with basil, a woodsy and earthy root vegetable soup simply simmered, a barely poached egg wrapped in toasted wrap atop a bernaise sauce). The meal ended with cookies surrounded by melting dry ice. It wasn't the "you can put me down now that I've eaten this spectacular culinary feat" type of meal, but it was an entertaining, delightful experience that made for wonderful foodie pics (yeah, I'm paying like $200 here, I'm taking my damn no-flash photo!).
